citeinfo.origin: Center for International Earth Science Information Network
citeinfo.title: CHGIS Version 4 : CITAS 1990 China Districts

descript.abstract: Administrative Regions (Districts) in the People's Republic of China, 1990.1990 CITAS Data China in Time and Space [CITAS] datasets have been reprojected to match the CHGIS base datasets.Separate polygon GIS layers are provided for provinces, prefectures, and counties. See the CHGIS China Dimensions page for a full description of the CITAS datasets.V4 County layers include statistical data from the 1990 census! See Counties description for details. -- text from CHGIS v4 CD-ROM.
descript.purpose: Redistribution of CITAS GIS dataset in CHGIS projection and format.The China Historical Geographic Information System (CHGIS) project is designed to provide a GIS platform for scholarly and scientific research. Considerable flexibility has been designed into the GIS, allowing for alternate versions and variations of feature attributes, spatial data, and competing political entities. The CHGIS aims to build a reliable database of administrative units and settlements, but does not wish to impose a closed interpretation on the relationships among those units. The advantage of creating the CHGIS, rather than printing paper maps, is that the relationships between the units can be modified and improved whenever new information becomes available and the new "edition" needs only to be posted on the Internet for users to download. The CHGIS editors have set high editorial standards for the inclusion of material in the CHGIS time series data and regulate the release of the official versions from designated CHGIS participating organizations. Users may search the database for administrative units and capitals for any given time in Chinese history, can create customized digital maps for particular times and places, or can join their own datasets for spatial analysis, thematic mapping, or other specialized statistical modeling according to their own interests.

idinfo.useconst: For non-commercial academic research purposes only.

cntaddr.address: Harvard Yenching Inst, 20 Van Serg, 25 Francis Avenue

idinfo.datacred: Copyright holders are CIESIN, NASA, CITAS, and Chinese Academy of Sciences
idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 2; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.2.0.1324

procstep.procdesc: ArcMap was used to edit the source shape files and delete the values in any columns containing Chinese characters, then the ArcGIS 9.2 Feature Class to Feature Class tool was used to move the geographic shapes into SDE. Microsoft Access was used to import the CHGIS-provided text file containing the properly encoded attribute values. A new text file containing just attributes with Chinese characters was created with the proper encoding, either GBK or UTF-8 depending on the source. This text file was imported to a new table in Oracle using SQLLoader with the NLS_CHARACTERSET property set to either UTF8 or ZHS16GBK. The attributes were then joined back to the shapes using Windows SQLPlus with the NLS_LANGUAGE property set to Traditional Chinese. This process ensured that the encoding was properly interpreted during the import.

attrdomv.udom: Text. [Chinese characters may not display properly on machines without the proper character sets installed.]

attr.attrdef: GB (Guo Biao -- National Standard) Codes for the Administrative Divisions of the People's Republic of China, 1991

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.
